children.content: History of foot trauma
Consider fracture or sprain
Perform plain radiography using anteroposterior (AP), medial oblique, and lateral views
Consider MRI for diagnosis
Pain and tenderness associated with particular joints or tendons
Squeezing across the base of the toes or across the foot at the highest point of the arch
See the chapters Polyarthritis and Monoarthritis
Perform radiographs
Nonarthritic musculoskeletal causes of foot pain
Pes cavus, pes planus, malalignment of the ankle at the tibiotalar joint, hallux valgus (bunion), and hammertoe
Pain and tenderness of the plantar aponeurosis, especially at its insertion into the calcaneus
Pain with resisted contraction of the relevant muscle group and often by passive stretching, point tenderness, or both
Morton's neuroma and synovial cysts are benign conditions presenting as painful nodules
Assess arterial flow, venous insufficiency
Arterial insufficiency
Perform Doppler ultrasound
Venous insufficiency
Perform Doppler testing to rule out deep venous thrombosis if unilateral foot swelling
Peripheral neuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex, small-fiber neuropathy, tarsal tunnel syndrome
Consider polyneuropathy, mononeuritis multiplex, small-fiber neuropathy, tarsal tunnel syndrome
Perform nerve conduction studies
Bacterial skin infection (cellulitis), periarthritis, stasis dermatitis
Consider infection, periarthritis, stasis dermatitis
